title.narrative: Forming small business to move families out of poverty in Ecuador´s south dry forest

description.narrative: The project, “Forming Small Businesses to Move Families Out of Poverty in Ecuador’s South Dry Forest” will work in the dry forests of southwestern Loja province, in the cantons located along the border with Peru (Espíndola, Macará, Celica, Paltas, Puyango and Zapotillo). The Dry Forest is one of the region’s most vulnerable ecosystems, because families extract resources indiscriminately to eke out their existence, planting monocrop corn under dry climatic conditions (24ºC average temperature, negative water regime, and mean annual precipitation of 600 mm). This ecosystem’s fragile nature means that there is little diversity in family livelihoods. In this context of a fragile ecosystem, the following problems in particular have been identified: a) Deficiency in links to produce and market three products with potential (corn, honey and basic staple products) to address from a value chain approach, b) one of families’ greatest problems with farming is low production, productivity and diversity on family farms, which leads to problems in food supply. c) lack of understanding about how vulnerable the dry forest is or how to adapt to climate change, so the ecosystem is improperly managed and without organizational coordination. d) Weaknesses in organizational processes to undertake economic ventures from a value chain perspective and to generate coordination within local governments and other entities. Municipalities are also weak in addressing productive development and generating environmental policies. This is why the project will address these issues, with the following goals: Impact Objective: Improve living conditions and opportunities for vulnerable families in the southwestern dry forests of the province of Loja, in a context of territorial coordination and adaptation to climate change, and with the following Specific Objectives: Objective 1: In 3 years, improve gross income by an average of 13% for 810 rural families by strengthening 3 value chains (honey, corn and basic staple foods) using agroforestry systems. Objective 2: Strengthen organizational and institutional processes to ensure coordination and sustainable management of the dry forest ecosystem. To achieve these objectives, the production chain for honey, corn (for animal feed and corn meal for human consumption) and basic staple foods will be strengthened, through a strategy including: rural public-private partnership to reinforce production and strengthen marketing; all with regulations and farming practices that are environmentally friendly to manage the dry forest. Families will receive: a. For production: seeds, tools, fertilizer, equipment and materials for post-harvest management and product transformation for the value chain. b. For marketing, operating capital and funds for marketing strategies will be provided for new economic undertakings. c. For organization-building, sustained training processes will be supported. The project will be implemented in a joint effort coordinated between the public sector, represented by the Dry Forest Mancomunidad; the Program for Good Living of the Ministry of Agriculture and Livestock (MAGAP) and the Decentralized Autonomous Provincial Government of Loja (GADPL) and the private sector represented by the Social Solidary Economics Program (PESS) currently under way in the province of Loja, led by the Intercooperation Latin America Foundation (Intercooperation). The project will have a duration of 3 years. Heifer Ecuador has worked in the zone for 12 years with 3 projects, oriented fundamentally toward sustainable management of the dry forest, coordinating organizations and backstopping the transition from monoculture to production based on agroecology. In the last 2 years, major opportunities have opened up for marketing small-farm produce.
